By extending the units with two additional links, a basic dual-ring combination unit composed of one spherical and one planar 4R mechanism is constructed. Based on screw theory and topological analysis, it is demonstrated that this unit's 1-DoF property remains unchanged during multi-module combination, ensuring consistent controllability in reconfiguration. Furthermore, we explored different chiral combination strategies of the units. A generalized input-output equation that captures the relationship between chirality arrangements and the displacement and rotation at the output end is proposed. Finally, these combination strategies are verified by a geometric optimized chiral units prototype, providing a novel solution for robotic design in intelligent manufacturing.

title: Modeling of Multiple Grid-Forming Devices and Analysis of Oscillation Mechanisms
authors: Qingxi Duan, Yu Duan, Xing Ma, Jian Ma, Jiahao Guo, Zhibang Shen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Smart Grid and Energy Engineering (SGEE)
abstract: The parallel operation of multiple grid-forming (GFM) converters under low-impedance conditions poses significant challenges to system stability. However, gaps remain in the existing literature regarding the small-signal modeling and accurate stability analysis of such multi-converter parallel systems, particularly within the context of low-impedance grids. This paper investigates the stability issues associated with the parallel operation of multiple GFM converters under low-impedance conditions. Initially, a state-space model for the multi-converter parallel system is developed. Subsequently, eigenvalue trajectory and dominant oscillation mode participation factor analyses are employed to investigate the impact of key parameters. The analysis reveals that under low-impedance operating conditions, the system's dominant eigenvalues migrate towards the unstable region as the grid strength increases or the coupling impedance decreases, thereby causing stability degradation. Finally, time-domain simulations conducted in MATLAB/Simulink validate these findings.

title: Machine Learning-Based Leak Detection in Urban Water Distribution Networks
authors: Tanay Kulkarni, Ayush Singh, Suchith Goud Arella
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on System Modeling &amp; Advancement in Research Trends (SMART)
abstract: Water distribution networks (WDNs) in cities are characterized by substantial losses in the operating and economic level because there is no detection of leakage, and the early identification and accurate localization are the urgent research interests. Although recent improvements in machine learning (ML) have been very promising, the existing systems are still limited to the problems of scarcity of data, sim-to-real generalization, sensor sparsity, and lack of generalization over heterogeneous networks. The old, supervised models like support vector machines and boosted trees are interpretable but they are not adaptable to the dynamic hydraulic conditions. Convolutional and recurrent neural network architecture frameworks are more sensitive to the fine details of anomalies; however, they require high-quality and large amounts of labelled data and cannot withstand topological variation. Graph neural networks take advantage of the spatial dependencies to have better localization but is computationally unstable, and they are hard to understand to operate on. Bayesian model based as well as hybrid methods add consistency to physics models as well as quantifying uncertainties but rely heavily on a precise calibration of hydraulic simulators. Moreover, the evaluation of most published work is done on synthetically written datasets, which creates issues concerning domain adaptation when issued to actual urban systems. As a remedy of these gaps, the proposed research suggests a physics-informed, uncertainty-calibrated ML system comprising of graph-aware representation learning, as well as domain adaptation techniques, trained semi-supervised on multi-modal sensing data. The purpose of the study is to (i) avoid dependence on large, labeled leak levels, (ii) improve sensitivity in different regime of demand and operation and (iii) offer interpretable and transferable detectors of different types of WDNs. The proposed framework will enhance the theoretical progress by allocating some advanced theoretical aspects into the applicability of research findings in practice and delivering a scalable, reliable, and deployable solution addressing urban water facilities.

title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Cancer Biomarker Detection and Analysis
authors: Shaikh Nusratullah, Ashish Anjankar, Archana Dhok, Mohd Basheeruddin, Rushikesh Ingole, Pratiksha Batulwar
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: AI has transformed biomarker discovery, assessment, and response in oncology. Cancer is one of the leading causes of mortality and disability globally, making accurate, early, and personalized diagnostic tools essential. AI-based methods are revolutionizing biomarker discovery by enhancing genomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and imaging data processing, pattern recognition, and prediction. Discover the latest AI-powered cancer biomarker discovery, characterization, and clinical application. This study will examine AI's usage in cancer care, including early identification, precise prognosis, therapeutic response prediction, and more. A review was done to discover relevant peer-reviewed literature. We selected publications on AIdriven biomarker creation in various cancers that fulfilled exclusion and inclusion criteria. AI, notably ML, DL, and radiomics, improved biomarker detection. These methods have improved biomarker sensitivity and specificity across several cancer types to improve clinical decision-making and therapy personalization. This study shows how AI might transform cancer biomarker discovery and use. Strong evidence for AI-based biomarkers in clinical oncology promotes precision medicine, early intervention, and optimal therapy courses.

title: LEVI-SAM: Tightly-Coupled LiDAR-Visual-Inertial Odometry with Event Cameras
authors: Kefan Lai, Tian Lan, Yingchun Zhao, Junyao Yan, Jianjun Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Biomimetics (ROBIO)
abstract: Event cameras, renowned for their microsecondlevel temporal resolution and high dynamic range (HDR), have shown remarkable potential in addressing challenges like motion blur and extreme illumination in visual odometry. LiDAR sensors capture rich structural information of the environment through 3D point clouds, delivering complementary geometric constraints that improve the accuracy and robustness of state estimation in large-scale scenarios. While LiDAR-visual fusion has been widely adopted in conventional SLAM systems, its integration with event cameras remains underexplored. This paper introduces LEVI-SAM, the first tightly coupled LiDAR-visual-inertial odometry(LVIO) with event cameras, designed to combine the strengths of standard cameras, event cameras and LiDAR for simultaneously localization and mapping(SLAM) in large-scale and high-speed scenarios. Experimental results on the ECMD dataset [1] demonstrate that our LEVI-SAM achieves comparable accuracy and enhanced robustness relative to existing LiDAR-inertial odometry(LIO) and LVIO approaches.

title: Signal Integrity Analysis of Interconnection Structures Using Conformal Finite-Difference Time-Domain Method
authors: Zhuohua Xie, Yan Peng, Huaguang Bao, Tiancheng Zhang, Zongguang Yu, Dazhi Ding
publish: 2025 Cross Strait Radio Science and Wireless Technology Conference (CSRSWTC)
abstract: This paper deduces an iterative algorithm of lumped element occupying multiple mesh by using the conformal finite-difference time-domain(CFDTD) method. The feasibility of the proposed method was verified through the signal integrity analysis of the partial interconnection structure of the chip. The computing efficiency has been improved through parallel computing.

title: Artificial Intelligence in the Diagnosis and Understanding of Primary Dysmenorrhea and Endometriosis: Emerging Insights and Clinical Implications
authors: Prerana Sakharwade, Bibin Kurian, Amar Taksande, Bharat Rathi, Achita Sawarkar
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: Menstrual illnesses, in particular, endometriosis and primary dysmenorrhea (PD) are highly prevalent yet largely ignored conditions that produce significant adverse productivity and quality of life changes. Traditional methods of diagnosis largely depend on the symptoms presented by the patient thus leading to underreporting, delay in diagnosis, and misdiagnosis. The recent advancements in the field of artificial intelligence (AI) have offered new opportunities to improve the accuracy of diagnosis and the understanding of the causes of the disease. One machine learning model that has demonstrated great performance in distinguishing between individuals with the Parkinson disease (PD) and healthy individuals is support vector machines (SVM) which is a model that uses neuroimaging to identify patterns of individuals brain competence. Like this, AI-based solutions, such as ensemble models such as extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) and natural language processing (NLP) have been shown to have the potential to forecast the risk of endometriosis and discover therapeutically relevant data. Although these developments are promising with earlier and more accurate diagnosis, there are still problems with the heterogeneity of data, small sample sizes, model interpretability and acceptance in clinical settings. To ensure equal accessibility and the ability to apply in practice, the implementation of AI in gynecological care requires careful validation, interdisciplinary collaboration, and ethics.

title: Feature-Enhanced Relation Extraction with Large Language Models
authors: Yihe Chi
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing (MLNLP)
abstract: Relation extraction transforms unstructured text into structured knowledge but faces a critical trade-off: neural methods require expensive fine-tuning of large models, while traditional feature-based approaches lack deep semantic understanding. We propose FERELL, a novel framework that leverages large language models as frozen feature extractors combined with traditional linguistic features. By keeping LLM parameters frozen, our approach eliminates fine-tuning costs while utilizing rich pre-trained representations. A lightweight fusion mechanism integrates LLM-derived semantic features with explicit linguistic structures. Experiments on NYT and WebNLG benchmarks show FERELL achieves state-of-the-art F1 scores with substantial improvements over previous best methods, while requiring significantly less computational resources and maintaining high efficiency in complex scenarios including overlapping relations.

title: DC-Link Discharge Resistance Design for Three-Phase Voltage-Source Converter Considering System Stability
authors: Ho-Jin Yang, Tae-Seok Kang, Hyun-Jin Jin, Jihun So, YoungGyu Jin, Yeong-Jun Choi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Smart Grid and Energy Engineering (SGEE)
abstract: In a voltage-source converter (VSC) system, capacitors are connected in series to withstand the high DC-link voltage. In this system, a discharge resistor connected in parallel with the capacitor is essential to mitigate voltage unbalance and ensure stable energy discharge. However, the discharge resistor generates low-frequency pole in the voltage-control loop, thereby reducing system stability. To analyze the impact of discharge resistors on system stability, it is necessary to consider both the value and number of discharge resistors applied to the system. Therefore, this paper presents a mathematical model of a VSC considering discharge resistors and analyzes impact on system stability through frequency-response analysis using bode plots. Based on the analytical results, this paper proposes design range for the discharge resistance to ensure system stability. The proposed design range is validated through hardware-in-the-Ioop (HIL) experiments using an RT -Box platform.

title: BLIP-3: A Family of Open Large Multimodal Models
authors: Le Xue, Manli Shu, Anas Awadalla, Jun Wang, An Yan, Senthil Purushwalkam, Honglu Zhou, Viraj Prabhu, Yutong Dai, Michael S Ryoo, Shrikant Kendre, Jieyu Zhang, Shaoyen Tseng, Gustavo A Lujan-Moreno, Matthew L Olson, Musashi Hinck, David Cobbley, Vasudev Lal, Can Qin, Shu Zhang, Chia-Chih Chen, Ning Yu, Juntao Tan, Tulika Manoj Awalgaonkar, Shelby Heinecke, Huan Wang, Yejin Choi, Ludwig Schmidt, Zeyuan Chen, Silvio Savarese, Juan Carlos Niebles, Caiming Xiong, Ran Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: This paper introduces BLIP-3, an open framework for developing Large Multimodal Models (LMMs). The framework comprises meticulously curated datasets, a training recipe, model architectures, and a resulting suite of LMMs. We release 4B and 14B models, including both the pre-trained base model and the instruction fine-tuned ones. Our models undergo rigorous evaluation across a range of tasks, including both single and multi-image benchmarks. Our models demonstrate competitive performance among open-source LMMs with similar model sizes. Our resulting LMMs demonstrate competitive performance among open-source LMMs with similar model sizes, with the ability to comprehend interleaved image-text inputs. Our training code, models, and all datasets used in this work, including the three large-scale datasets we create and the preprocessed ones, will be open-sourced to better support the research community.

title: Hybrid Robotic Hand for Fabric Manipulation with a Single-Finger
authors: Xinhao Chen, Alberto Elías Petrilli Barceló, Dayuan Chen, Jose Victorio Salazar Luces, Yasuhisa Hirata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Biomimetics (ROBIO)
abstract: With increasing labor shortages and growing production demands, the automation of garment manufacturing is developing rapidly. Among the various processes, fabric handling and manipulation account for nearly 80% of the total production time, making fabric grasping a critical step in the workflow. Traditional fabric manipulation typically uses low-degree-of-freedom (low-DOF) grippers to simplify hardware design. However, due to the unique and highly dynamic characteristics of fabric, such methods face significant challenges in algorithm development and task adaptability. To address these issues, we propose a novel robotic hand design that integrates multiple grasping types and principles, enabling it to meet diverse task requirements. The design also incorporates industrial features such as a reduced number of actuators and simplified mechanical structure, facilitating practical deployment. Based on this concept, we have developed two versions of a robotic hand specifically designed for fabric grasping. This paper presents an improved version of the design, optimized for better adaptability to different operation scenarios and enhanced actuation efficiency. Experimental results validate the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed design.

title: Research on Short-Term Load Forecasting Methods for Integrated Mine Energy Systems Considering Source-Load Uncertainty
authors: Huiqun Huang, Yingnan Guo, Zhen Song, Xia Zhang, Yongteng Du, Chunyang Yue, Rui Zhang, Qingzhao Ma, Yan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Energy Power and Electrical Technology (CEPET)
abstract: Mining energy is a key application scenario for achieving the dual carbon goals, and the efficient operation of its systems is crucial for industrial green transformation. However, uncertainties on both the supply and demand sides pose significant challenges for system scheduling: supply-side wind and solar power generation fluctuates dramatically, while demand-side production processes exhibit random load variations. Traditional forecasting methods struggle to effectively capture the dynamic patterns of such highly nonlinear loads. This paper proposes a short-term load forecasting model that integrates Variational Modal Decomposition (VMD), attention mechanisms, and a bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network. The model reduces the non-stationarity of load sequences through VMD decomposition, utilizes the BiLSTM-Attention architecture to extract temporal features, and enhances the model’s adaptability to uncertainty factors by incorporating multi-source features. The results show that the model proposed in this study significantly outperforms the comparison models, validating its effectiveness and practicality in mine load forecasting. This provides reliable technical support for optimizing the scheduling of mine energy systems.

title: Operationalising Political Style: A Diagnostic Model for Governmental Speeches During the Pandemic
authors: André Schmale
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Social Networks Analysis, Management and Security (SNAMS)
abstract: This case study analyzes 15 government speeches in seven languages in which the first measures to contain the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus were announced in 2020. Based on the combination of political discourse analysis, framing theory, and narrative analysis, the study develops a cross-linguistic diagnostic model that links linguistic forms such as lexical diversity, readability, and polarity with discursive actions aimed at constructing political legitimacy and authority. The analytical framework combines sentiment recognition, structural topic modeling (STM), and text network analysis. These components make it possible to classify each speech in a structured way along two axes: linguistic complexity and emotional tonality. The diagnostic model distinguishes between simple and complex communication styles and captures whether language use is based on passive or active action orientation. This approach enables a systematic, language-independent comparison of rhetorical strategies. Beyond its descriptive utility, the model provides a transferable analytical framework for future quantitative research on political language.

title: Tawa: Automatic Warp Specialization for Modern GPUs with Asynchronous References
authors: Hongzheng Chen, Bin Fan, Alexander Collins, Bastian Hagedorn, Evghenii Gaburov, Masahiro Masuda, Matthew Brookhart, Chris Sullivan, Jason Knight, Zhiru Zhang, Vinod Grover
publish: 2026 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO)
abstract: Modern GPUs feature specialized hardware units that enable high-performance, asynchronous dataflow execution. However, the conventional SIMT programming model is fundamentally misaligned with this task-parallel hardware, creating a significant programmability gap. While hardware-level warp specialization is the key to unlocking peak performance, it forces developers to manually orchestrate complex, low-level communication and software pipelines—a process that is labor-intensive, error-prone, and unsustainable. To address this challenge, we present Tawa, an automated compiler that systematically generates high-performance, warp-specialized code from a high-level, tile-based program. Central to our approach is a novel IR abstraction, asynchronous references (aref), which expresses warp-level communication without exposing low-level hardware details. Using this abstraction, Tawa automatically partitions programs into producer-consumer roles and manages the intricate dataflow pipeline, relieving developers of invasive kernel rewriting. Evaluation on NVIDIA H100 GPUs across representative LLM kernels shows that Tawa delivers high hardware utilization, achieving up to 1.1 × speedup over highly optimized cuBLAS GEMM kernels. For attention workloads, Tawa attains 1.2× speedup over Triton and matches the performance of the hand-optimized CUTLASS C++ FlashAttention-3 kernel with far less programming effort.

title: Binary Diffing via Library Signatures
authors: Andrei Rimsa, Anderson Faustino Da Silva, Camilo Santana, Fernando Magno Quintão Pereira
publish: 2026 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO)
abstract: Binary diffing is the problem of determining whether two binary programs originate from the same source code. Binary diffing tools are used to identify malware, plagiarism, or code theft. Many instances of binary diffing assume an adversarial setting, where a malicious actor transforms binary code by changing the compiler. Traditional diffing techniques rely on statistical similarity analysis, often leveraging stochastic models. However, recent studies have shown that these classifiers perform poorly in the face of adversarial code transformations. To mitigate this scenario, this paper introduces a new diffing technique that is resilient against current obfuscation approaches. We propose comparing executables by matching their library signatures (libsig). A program’s library signature is the sequence of calls it makes to functions outside its .text section. The proposed classifier, LibSIG, is faster than off-the-shelf alternatives, such as ltrace, and, like it, works on stripped binaries or binaries running with address space layout randomization (ASLR) enabled. Furthermore, in contrast to ltrace, LibSIG can be engineered to detect even library calls that bypass conventional application binary interface patterns. Our experiments on the GNU Core Utilities demonstrate that LibSIG remains robust against obfuscators like Khaos and ollvm, as well as typical optimization patterns, outperforming binary diffing approaches such as SAFE, BinDiff, or Asm2Vec.

title: Integrating AI into DevSecOps Pipelines for Secure Cloud Microservices Management
authors: Atish Kumar Dash
publish: 2026 IEEE 5th International Conference on AI in Cybersecurity (ICAIC)
abstract: The modern era of technology encompasses many innovative areas such as cloud computing and the applications and services within them. These workloads, primarily based on microservices architectures, have ushered in blazing fast applications and cloud services. The entire lifecycle of these workloads embedded within traditional DevOps model has been redefined with a shift left approach to security. This is where DevSecOps promises to be a major game changer in this context. This paper explores the overall merger between such cloud workloads and artificial intelligence (AI). While such a combination is pretty much in its nascent stage, this study delves deeper into ways in which such integrations can work seamlessly across stakeholders. The issues of containerized workloads across various pipeline stages, including code commit, build, testing, deployment, and runtime monitoring are investigated and given adequate attention. The paper also explores the trade-offs involved in meeting exponential consumer demand with improved security and threat surface minimization of these cloud-based microservices inclusive of real-world examples. The current AI-driven security automation processes are examined and the limitations of such static rule based, and reactive models are also touched upon. AI-driven techniques such as anomaly detection, predictive risk scoring, intelligent vulnerability prioritization, and automated policy enforcement are further looked at from a regulatory perspective for large enterprise environments. AI-driven DevSecOps provides a step forward in enhancing the security and reliability of cloud-native applications. The present study further calls out AI explainability and real-world validation, specifically from a microservices architecture standpoint and how to manage them effectively to accelerate industry wide adoption.

title: CoralVOS: Dataset and Benchmark for Dense Coral Video Segmentation
authors: Ziqiang Zheng, Haixin Liang, Yaofeng Xie, Zhibin Yu, Sai-Kit Yeung
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: Coral reefs form the most valuable and productive marine ecosystems, providing habitat for a wide range of marine species. Coral reef surveying and analysis are currently confined to coral experts who invest substantial efforts in generating comprehensive and reliable reports (e.g., coral coverage, population, spatial distribution, etc). However, performing coral analysis based on manual efforts is significantly time-consuming and expensive; the existing coral analytical approaches compromise and opt for performing down-sampling and then conducting sparse point-based coral analysis within selected frames from the whole video. However, such down-sampling will introduce the estimation bias (under-lover- estimation) or even lead to wrong results. To address this issue, we propose to perform dense coral video segmentation, with no down-sampling involved during the whole analysis procedure. Through coral video segmentation, we could generate more reliable and in-depth coral analysis than existing coral reef analytical approaches. To boost such dense coral analysis, we propose a large-scale coral video segmentation dataset CoralVOS as demonstrated in Figure 1. To the best of our knowledge, our CoralVOS is the first dataset to support dense coral video segmentation. We perform experiments on our CoralVOS dataset, including 6 recent video object segmentation (VOS) algorithms. We fine-tuned these VOS algorithms on our CoralVOS dataset and achieved observable performance improvements. The results show that the coral reef analysis will greatly benefit from the coral video segmentation, and there is still great potential for further promoting the segmentation accuracy. Finally, we demonstrate that the proposed CoralVOS could promote coral population estimation, spatial coral reef modeling, and 3D coral reef reconstruction. Dataset and our labeling tool are available at https://coralvos.hkustvgd.com/.

title: Research on Cooperative Control Algorithm for S-Curve Trajectory Tracking and Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance of Autonomous Vehicles Based on MPC
authors: Zhaoyang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, and Communication (ICAIRC)
abstract: To address the issues of precise S-curve trajectory tracking and obstacle avoidance for autonomous vehicles in dynamic obstacle environments, this paper proposes an integrated algorithm based on Model Predictive Control (MPC). Firstly, a vehicle dynamic model (instead of a simplified kinematic model) that matches actual motion characteristics is constructed. The inertial coordinate system (XOY) and the vehicle body coordinate system (xoy) are introduced to describe key states such as position, velocity, and yaw angle. The decomposition formula of the rear axle center velocity and the discrete state equation under the XOY coordinate system are derived, laying a foundation for control design. This model fully considers longitudinal and lateral tire forces, vehicle mass and inertia properties, and actuator bandwidth limitations to more realistically reflect the dynamic response of the vehicle. Based on this model, the algorithm designs a quadratic programming objective function that includes state errors and control quantity changes: the weight matrix <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q$</tex> (diag (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{qx}, \text{qy}, \mathrm{q} \theta$</tex>)) in the state error term ensures lateral tracking accuracy, while the matrix R restricts sudden changes in longitudinal velocity and front-wheel steering angle to ensure stability. Dynamic obstacle avoidance is converted into linear constraints to define the range of control inputs. Meanwhile, a moving obstacle prediction model is introduced to predict the future positions of obstacles within the MPC prediction horizon. The collision avoidance constraints are reconstructed into time-varying constraints, covering the predicted positions of the vehicle and obstacles at each time step, thus forming a complete optimization problem. Matlab simulations verify the effectiveness of the algorithm: the actual trajectory highly matches the S-curve reference trajectory without obvious deviations; when facing dynamic obstacles, the input is adjusted in real-time to maintain a safe distance and avoid collisions; the state variables respond stably, and the tracking error converges to near zero. Compared with traditional methods such as PID, this MPC algorithm performs better in handling multi-variable constraints and nonlinear paths, providing a reliable solution for autonomous vehicles in complex traffic scenarios.

title: CrossGAP: Unified Face Anti-Spoofing via Cross-Modal Global-Aware Prompting
authors: Xihong Chen, Yutong Xie, Hui Ma, Ning Li, Yanyan Liang, Jiabao Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: Facial recognition systems remain vulnerable to both physical (e.g., printed photos) and digital (e.g., deep-fakes, face swaps) presentation attacks. Existing face antispoofing (FAS) methods struggle to simultaneously detect these attack types due to: (1) substantial divergence in visual characteristics, and (2) difficulties in learning unified cross-modal representations. To overcome these limitations, we propose CrossGAP, a unified FAS framework that leverages CLIP's cross-modal capabilities to detect diverse face attacks. Our model employs a global [CLS] token to capture holistic facial semantics, enhancing discrimination of physical and digital spoofing cues. Furthermore, we introduce a hierarchical prompt integration strategy to improve generalization across attack scenarios. Experiments demonstrate that CrossGAP achieves state-of-the-art performance in detecting both attack types.

title: Multimodal Representation Alignment for Image Generation: Text-Image Interleaved Control is Easier than You Think
authors: Liang Chen, Shuai Bai, Wenhao Chai, Weichu Xie, Haozhe Zhao, Leon Vinci, Junyang Lin, Baobao Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: The field of advanced text-to-image generation is witnessing the emergence of unified frameworks that integrate powerful text encoders, such as CLIP and T5, with Diffusion Transformer backbones. Although there have been efforts to control output images with additional conditions, like canny and depth map, a comprehensive framework for arbitrary text-image interleaved control is still lacking. This gap is especially evident when attempting to merge concepts or visual elements from multiple images in the generation process. To mitigate the gap, we conducted preliminary ex-periments showing that large multimodal models (LMMs) offer an effective shared representation space, where image and text can be well-aligned to serve as a condition for external diffusion models. Based on this discovery, we propose Dream Engine, an efficient and unified frame-work designed for arbitrary text-image interleaved control in image generation models. Building on powerful text-to-image models like SD3.5, we replace the original text-only encoders by incorporating versatile multimodal information encoders such as Qwen VL. Our approach utilizes a two-stage training paradigm, consisting of joint text-image alignment and multimodal interleaved instruction tuning. Our experiments demonstrate that this training method is effective, achieving a 0.69 overall score on the GenEval benchmark, and matching the performance of state-of-the-art text-to-image models like SD3.5 and FLUX.

title: Forgetting-Free Incremental Panoptic Lifting by Maximum-Visibility Viewpoint Selection
authors: Akira Kohjin, Motoharu Sonogashira, Masaaki Iiyama, Yasutomo Kawanishi
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: We propose an incremental learning method for Panoptic Lifting, a novel view synthesis technique that leverages both RGB images and panoptic segmentation masks to represent a 3D scene. While Panoptic Lifting is valuable in applications such as VR, autonomous vehicles, and robotics, it faces a challenge when observations are limited (e.g., due to occlusions), as retraining from scratch becomes computationally expensive. Our approach incrementally updates the model to achieve high accuracy with reduced computational cost. To prevent catastrophic forgetting, a phenomenon where previous learned knowledge is lost during model updates, We introduce a viewpoint selection algorithm that solves a maximum coverage problem to identify a subset of viewpoints that maximizes the visibility of the scene. Experimental results demonstrate a 12% reduction in computation time compared to the naïve approach, while effectively preventing catastrophic forgetting.

title: Impact of Black-Box Adversarial Attacks on Deep Neural Networks for Skin Imaging
authors: Bartłomiej Moniak, Joanna Jaworek-Korjakowska
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: Adversarial attacks have emerged as a critical threat vector against deep learning models, enabling the manipulation of model outputs through carefully crafted input perturbations. In this study, we explore the effectiveness of three black-box adversarial attack methodologies-where the attacker has no access to model internals-in the context of skin image classification. Using clinically relevant dermatological image datasets, we demonstrate that these attacks can reliably degrade the predictive performance of state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks, even under strict black-box constraints. We evaluate the proposed approach using black-box, noise-driven adversarial perturbations, including uniform random noise, Gaussian-masked noise, and anatomically-constrained noise guided by segmentation masks generated via the Segment Anything v2 (SAM2) model. The proposed black-box attacks resulted in a significant reduction in model accuracy (up to 23.75%) and F1-Score (as much as 50% drop). These results reveal a critical vulnerability of medical image classifiers to adversarial attacks and the importance of incorporating robust safety mechanisms during model development and deployment. The proposed models employ transfer learning using architectures such as ResNet-50 and EfficientNet (B0,B4, and B7). Training is conducted in two phases: initially, the backbone is frozen while a custom classification head is trained to adapt to the skin imaging domain. Subsequently, a two-stage unfreezing strategy is applied, grad-ually fine-tuning deeper layers of the network to improve task-specific feature representation. All models are trained on ISIC archive datasets, utilizing the 3D whole-body scans from ISIC 2024 and dermoscopic images from ISIC 2018 to ensure diversity in acquisition modalities and improve generalization across clinically relevant input types.

title: Research and Implementation of Humanoid Robot Footstepping Method Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning and Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Li Yue, Liu Mingshuo, Kang Ningjing, Zhao Guodong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Biomimetics (ROBIO)
abstract: This paper proposes a method combining Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) for optimizing the generation of stepping motions in humanoid robots. In this paper, a multi-objective reward function is designed through DRL to improve stability and motion efficiency, and RNN (such as LSTM) is used to enhance the ability of temporal action modeling and improve adaptability to dynamic environments. The experiments in this paper are conducted using Webots simulation software and the Darwin-OP2 robot, which verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: An Intelligent Bid Evaluation System for the Energy Industry Based on Large Language Models
authors: Rui Wang, Yu Zhao, Chunyu Han, Xingqi Feng, Kanglong Liu, Zhe Ji
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Robotics, Intelligent Control and Artificial Intelligence (RICAI)
abstract: The evaluation process for bidding in the energy sector is in urgent need of smart, super transparent, and reliable automated solutions because the documents involved are multimodal, the rules are complex, and the decisions made are really important. To tackle the issues that general big language models face in this high-stakes decision-making scene, like not having enough domain knowledge, unclear reasoning processes, and not following strict rules well, this paper introduces a smart bid evaluation system based on big models. This system uses a framework called “multi-modal evidence-driven explainable evaluation.” Its heart is a five-layer setup that brings together detailed document parsing and semantic searching, domainadaptive retrieval-augmented generation tech, and a hybrid scoring engine that mixes rule logic with statistical learning. This engine puts deterministic compliance checks as penalties into the data-driven scoring model, making sure decisions are compliant and explainable. On an energy bidding dataset with 900 real and made-up cases, this system got a Spearman's rank correlation coefficient of 0.78 with expert judgments on scoring consistency, an NDCG@5 of 0.86 on key bid rankings, and an F1 score of 0.90 on qualification classification, way better than many baseline models. Ablation experiments proved how effective the main parts, like retrieval-augmented generation and rule constraints, are. Plus, the system was tougher under simulated OCR noise and semantic attacks and got way higher explainability scores in blind human tests thanks to visual evidence and natural language explanations. This study offers a workable tech path and realworld example for building reliable, auditable smart decision-making systems for the industry.

title: CAFE: Unifying Representation and Generation with Contrastive-Autoregressive Finetuning
authors: Hao Yu, Zhuokai Zhao, Shen Yan, Lukasz Korycki, Jianyu Wang, Baosheng He, Jiayi Liu, Lizhu Zhang, Xiangjun Fan, Hanchao Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: The rapid advancement of large vision-language models (LVLMs) has driven significant progress in multimodal tasks, enabling models to interpret, reason, and generate outputs across both visual and textual domains. While excelling in generative tasks, existing LVLMs often face limitations in tasks requiring high-fidelity representation learning, such as generating image or text embeddings for retrieval. Recent work has proposed finetuning LVLMs for representational learning, but the finetuned model often loses its generative capabilities due to the representational learning training paradigm. To address this trade-off, we introduce CAFE, a contrastive-autoregressive fine-tuning framework that enhances LVLMs for both representation and generative tasks. By integrating a contrastive objective with autoregressive language modeling, our approach unifies these traditionally separate tasks, achieving state-of-the-art results in both multimodal retrieval and multimodal generative benchmarks, including object hallucination (OH) mitigation. CAFE establishes a novel frame work that synergizes embedding and generative functionalities in a single model, setting a foundation for future multimodal models that excel in both retrieval precision and coherent output generation.

title: ProtoMedX: Towards Explainable Multi-Modal Prototype Learning for Bone Health Classification
authors: Alvaro Lopez Pellicer, André Mariucci, Plamen Angelov, Marwan Bukhari, Jemma G. Kerns
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: Bone health studies are crucial in medical practice for the early detection and treatment of Osteopenia and Osteoporosis. Clinicians usually make a diagnosis based on densitometry (DEXA scans) and other patient history. The applications of AI in this field are an ongoing research. Most of the successful methods for this task include Deep Learning models that rely on vision alone (DEXA / X-ray imagery) geared towards high prediction accuracy, where explainability is disregarded and largely based on the post hoc assessment of input contributions. We propose ProtoMedX, a multi-modal model that uses both DEXA scans of the lumbar spine and patient records. ProtoMedX's prototype-based architecture is explainable by design, crucial for medical applications, especially in the context of the upcoming EU AI Act, as it allows explicit analysis of the model's decisions, especially the ones that are incorrect. ProtoMedX demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in bone health classification while also providing explanations that can be visually understood by clinicians. Using our dataset of 4,160 real NHS patients, the proposed ProtoMedX achieves 87.58% accuracy in vision-only tasks and 89.8% in its multi-modal variant, both approaches surpassing existing published methods.

title: Research on Power Frequency Waveform Classification for Transmission Lines Based on a Cascaded XGBoost Model
authors: Han Li, Yongqiang Zhao, Weihao Tan, Huaqing Wang, Jiaxing Li, Ting Lei
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Smart Grid and Energy Engineering (SGEE)
abstract: Accurate classification of power frequency waveforms is critical for transmission line fault location. While deep learning models (LSTM, CNN) show promise on idealized data, their practical application is constrained by three major challenges: dependency on simulated data, poor performance on imbalanced real-world datasets, and high computational costs requiring GPU resources. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a cascaded XGBoost model specifically designed for real-grid environments. Our approach decomposes the seven-class waveform classification task into a sequence of binary decisions with tailored feature engineering, enabling effective learning from actual grid data with inherent imbalance. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over conventional deep learning models, achieving 94.1% overall accuracy, 95.0% macro-average F1-score, and 94.1% weighted-average F1-score while completing training approximately 109 times faster than the LSTM model and 19 times faster than the CNN model. The model's computational efficiency and reliability on CPU-only systems make it particularly suitable for resource-constrained fault diagnosis applications.

title: Lightweight Spatio-Temporal Attention Network with Graph Embedding and Rotational Position Encoding for Traffic Forecasting
authors: Xiao Wang, Shun-Ren Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Service Operations and Logistics, and Informatics (SOLI)
abstract: Traffic forecasting is a key task in the field of Intelligent Transportation Systems. Recent research on traffic forecasting has mainly focused on combining graph neural networks (GNNs) with other models. However, GNNs only consider short-range spatial information. In this study, we present a novel model termed LSTAN-GERPE (Lightweight Spatio-Temporal Attention Network with Graph Embedding and Rotational Position Encoding). This model leverages both Temporal and Spatial Attention mechanisms to effectively capture long-range traffic dynamics. Additionally, the optimal frequency for rotational position encoding is determined through a grid search approach in both the spatial and temporal attention mechanisms. This systematic optimization enables the model to effectively capture complex traffic patterns. The model also enhances feature representation by incorporating geographical location maps into the spatio-temporal embeddings. Without extensive feature engineering, the proposed method in this paper achieves advanced accuracy on the real-world traffic forecasting datasets PeMS04 and PeMS08.

title: Heterogeneous Exoskeleton Teleoperation for Humanoid Upper-bodies: Elbow-Constrained Retargeting with ZNN
authors: Pengfei Wang, Huaqiang Zheng, Youshuang Ding, Ge Gao, Jianwei Zhang, Zongdao Li, Qingdu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Biomimetics (ROBIO)
abstract: The skill learning of humanoid robots largely relies on human skills, and their data sources are mostly obtained through human teleoperation. However, except for teleoperation devices that are isomorphic with the robot, which can accurately reflect the complete movements of the operator's arm, all other devices can only map the spatial pose of the arm's end-effector. Here we propose a retargeting method and a ZNN model for the real-time solution of this problem, enabling operators to remotely control the upper limbs of humanoid robots using a non-isomorphic wearable exoskeleton. By incorporating the operator's elbow joint as a constraint, the robot's arms can reproduce the operator's movements more accurately and naturally. Finally, remote control tests are conducted on three virtual humanoid robots with different configurations, as well as a physical counterpart of one of them. The results demonstrate that the proposed method provides a universal strategy for teleoperation with heterogeneous wearable exoskeletons, which not only exhibits good real-time performance but also enables more accurate reproduction of the operator's arm postures.

title: A Wideband Decoupling Method for Patch Antennas in MIMO Systems
authors: Yunyi Jiang, Changzhan Gu
publish: 2025 Cross Strait Radio Science and Wireless Technology Conference (CSRSWTC)
abstract: A planar patch antenna with E-plane decoupling is proposed to suppress strong mutual coupling in compact configurations. Edge truncation is applied to the rectangular patch to shift the intrinsic transmission zero. Two metallic strips are further introduced to excite an additional resonant mode and generate a transmission zero, resulting in improved bandwidth. Simulated results show that the antenna operates from 4.56 to 5.09 GHz, corresponding to a 10.98% impedance bandwidth, with isolation greater than 23.1 dB and a peak value of 48.1 dB.

title: Knowledge-Enhanced Bayesian Text Modeling and Analysis via Document Embedding and Clustering
authors: Gianni Costa, Riccardo Ortale
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing (MLNLP)
abstract: Clustering and representation learning are fundamental tasks in processing textual data. This paper presents a unified, knowledge-enhanced approach that integrates both tasks to improve their effectiveness. The proposed approach is grounded in a Bayesian model of text corpora, which formalizes a joint generative process where clustering and representation learning interact as latent factors. External knowledge is incorporated through word and entity embeddings to enrich the resulting representations and capture deeper semantic and syntactic patterns. Empirical results on benchmark datasets show that the proposed approach overcomes in effectiveness conventional methods for clustering and representation learning.

title: Multi-Scale Attention Residual Network for Flexible Sensor-Based Human Activity Recognition
authors: Kang Huang, Jiayi Yang, Tingting Yu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Robotics, Intelligent Control and Artificial Intelligence (RICAI)
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) based on wearable sensors has significant applications in health monitoring and rehabilitation. However, existing methods have limitations in multi-scale feature fusion and distinguishing confusable actions. This paper proposes MSAR-Net (Multi-Scale Attention Residual Network), a deep learning architecture designed for flexible strain sensors. The model extracts multi-scale features through five-stage progressive convolution with Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) attention, captures bidirectional temporal dependencies using Bi-LSTM, and implements dynamic global weighting via multi-head self-attention (MHSA). To address class imbalance, an adaptive data augmentation strategy and contrastive learning loss are designed. On the FSS-HAR dataset, MSAR-Net achieves 96.74% accuracy, outperforming deep learning baseline LSTM by 6.44 percentage points, and surpassing recent state-of-the-art time series models Inception Time and TapNet by 2.18 and 1.39 percentage points respectively, while maintaining <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$29-36 {\%}$</tex> fewer parameters and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 1}-\mathbf{2 9}{\%}$</tex> faster inference. Cross-dataset validation shows 98.9% and 97.3% accuracy on WISDM and UCIHAR datasets, demonstrating excellent generalization capability. Ablation experiments confirm the effectiveness of each module, with multi-head self-attention contributing the most (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+2.80 {\%}$</tex>).

title: Sweating the Stress: GSR Insights into Cognitive Load and Distraction
authors: Santiago Clemente, Layla Varghese, Valentina Nino, Maria Valero
publish: 2025 IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision Workshops (ICCVW)
abstract: Cognitive tasks often trigger measurable physiological stress responses, which can be amplified by environmental distractions. This study explores how cognitive load and auditory interruptions influence stress, using Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) as a biomarker of arousal. Eleven participants (ages 15–45, 6 female, 5 male) completed a series of alternating math and memory tasks under two conditions: a standard task and a disrupted version featuring sudden loud stimuli, including alarms and hand claps, delivered at the 30-second mark. Each task was preceded and followed by two-minute rest periods to establish baseline and recovery metrics. GSR data were recorded using a finger-mounted sensor at an adjusted frequency between 1–100 Hz and processed to extract tonic and phasic components. Event-related analyses focused on time-locked peaks around the distraction stimuli. Results showed significantly elevated mean and peak GSR values during task phases, with higher responses during the distraction condition. Phasic peaks exhibited faster rise times and higher amplitudes post-stimulus. These findings underscore the sensitivity of GSR to detect real-time stress induced by cognitive effort and abrupt environmental stimuli, offering potential for adaptive systems in human-computer interaction and workload-aware designs<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>Database of the study can be downloaded at https://tinyurl.com/gsrdataset.

title: A Frequency Selective Rasorber Based on an Integrated Absorptive Structure
authors: Kai Li, Peng Liu, Wenjun Zhou, Qingdong Zhang
publish: 2025 Cross Strait Radio Science and Wireless Technology Conference (CSRSWTC)
abstract: A frequency selective rasorber (FSR) based on an integrated absorbing structure is proposed in this paper. The designed FSR exhibits high transmission efficiency and a low radar cross-section (RCS) for electromagnetic waves under both TE and TM polarizations. The structure comprises an integrated lossy layer on the top and a broadband bandpass frequency selective surface (FSS) at the bottom, yielding high transmission within the passband and high absorption outside it. Full-wave simulation results show a transmission band (defined by 1.3 dB insertion loss) from 9.07 to 12.23 GHz. Furthermore, the absorption exceeds 80% in two separate bands: 3.75 - 7.91 GHz and 13.53 - 16.04 GHz.

title: An Innovative Approach to Cardiac Care: Using Artificial Intelligence to Predict and Prevent Sudden Cardiac Arrest
authors: Sana Qausain, Mohd. Basheeruddin, Ashish Anjankar, Faez Iqbal Khan, Akshat Jain, Rushikesh P Ingole
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: Sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) is a leading cause of mortality in the world that requires quick detection and immediate intervention. Traditional diagnostic measures are in most cases destined to overlook insidious pre-cardiac symptoms. Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) are other methods of Artificial Intelligence (AI) that provide solutions to early prediction when real-time multimodal inputs and outputs are present (ECG, PPG, HRV, and EHRs). The AI is able to identify non-linear trends, which are not visible to traditional methods, to provide early risk assessment. This paper introduces a hybrid framework of AI that combines deep signal processing and clinical data mining to create personalized alerts and risk profiles. It also raises such issues as the security of data, transparency of the model, and clinical flexibility. The reinforcement of interdisciplinary work will be beneficial in improving AI-based systems, facilitating proactive cardiovascular care and cutting down SCA-induced fatalities.

title: BioCrest - A Flexible Adaptive Robotic Hand Based on Idle-Stroke Mechanism*
authors: Haokai Ding, Xianjie Zhong, Wenke Huang, Tao Yang, Wenzeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Biomimetics (ROBIO)
abstract: Simultaneously achieving precision pinching and compliant grasping with active adaptation remains a significant challenge for most robotic hands and grippers. Furthermore, actively transitioning between grasping postures is difficult for hands or grippers with limited degrees of freedom (DOF). Even dexterous hands with high DOF often require extensive control strategies and extensive information from tactile sensors. This paper introduces BioCrest, a two-finger, three-DOF adaptive gripper exhibiting active reconfiguration capability. Each finger comprises the minimal number of components: three rigid links, one flexure strip, and one fingertip. Both fingers are actuated by a single shared motor. This simple yet unique finger structure enables both precise parallel pinching and highly compliant, stable grasping with uniform pressure distribution. A lost-motion transmission mechanism facilitates fingertip angle adjustment. Comprehensive kinematic and force analyses, combined with detailed mechanical design descriptions, clearly demonstrate controllable transition characteristics and stable grasping performance, including grasping force characteristics. Experiments validate the performance of the proposed gripper and demonstrate its practical utility in real-world applications.

title: Investigation of Dielectric Characteristics of Non-Uniform Moisture in Epoxy-Impregnated Paper Based on Frequency Domain Dielectric Spectroscopy
authors: Xiaohui Yan, Hao Yang, Yuanshuai He, Yu Hou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Smart Grid and Energy Engineering (SGEE)
abstract: Epoxy-impregnated paper (RIP) is widely used in dry-type bushings for smart grids, yet moisture ingress remains a critical threat to its insulation integrity. Existing research lacks focused investigation on the Frequency Domain Dielectric Spectroscopy under non-uniform moisture distribution. This paper proposes a novel method for fabricating geometrically simplified RIP samples and controlling localized moisture ingress within designated interlayers. A dedicated test platform was established to measure the Frequency Domain Dielectric Spectroscopy (FDS) of the samples (1mHz ~5 kHz) under varying moisture locations and concentrations. Results indicate that the dielectric loss tangent (tan δ) is highly sensitive to both moisture content and its spatial distribution. Moisture closer to the measuring electrode primarily increases the low-frequency conductive loss, while moisture on both sides of the central aluminum foil enhances the interfacial and dipole polarization losses at mid-to-high frequencies, concurrently exhibiting a significant suppressive effect on the low-frequency dielectric loss. These findings provide a crucial foundation for non-destructive, condition-based monitoring and diagnostic strategies for assessing moisture states within dry-type bushings, thereby contributing to enhanced asset management in smart grids.

title: Explainable AI for Early Detection and Treatment of Blood Cancer: Enhancing Transparency and Trust in Oncology
authors: Sushma Sugrivrao Gaikwad
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: One of the most serious health problems affecting individuals worldwide is blood cancer, which typically results from environmental and hereditary factors. Since detecting and treating cancer is one of the most challenging tasks in modern medicine, experts are focusing their attention on developing focused and precise techniques to improve patient outcomes. The humanization of explainable AI (XAI), a vital tool for improving the transparency and understandability of AI-based decision making, has emerged as the most promising avenue in recent years. Blood cancer is one of the most deadly illnesses in the world today, This is brought about by the interaction of genetic and nongenetic factors. In both developed and developing countries, It is among the primary causes of death from cancer. After outlining traditional AI methods for cancer detection and highlighting knowledge gaps, this paper explores the fundamentals of XAI. By examining its possible influence on this subject, it investigates the function of XAI in cancer detection and treatment. The diagnosis of medical imaging data is presented first, followed by a discussion of how a XAI system would analyze patient data and how therapeutic treatments will be optimized to create patient-specific treatment plans. The use of XAI to cancer screening and treatment strategies will decide future oncology practice. This will not only alter precision medicine but also dramatically improve patient care.

title: Research on Multi-Modal Data Fusion Technology for Detection and Assessment of Transmission Line Defects
authors: Shuai Guo, Xiangyu Zhao, Ruiye Zhou, Qinyu Feng, Huanming Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Energy Power and Electrical Technology (CEPET)
abstract: This study aims to improve the accuracy of transmission line defect detection and the reliability of risk assessment. It addresses the issue of insufficient detection capability in complex scenarios using existing methods, by applying multi-modal data fusion technology. A multi-modal detection and assessment framework is proposed, which integrates visible light, infrared, and LiDAR point cloud data. The YOLOv7 model is improved by introducing a coordinate attention mechanism to enhance small object detection capabilities, and the Focal-EIoU loss function is employed to optimize bounding box regression. A bidirectional cross-modal attention module is designed to achieve deep feature fusion between visible light and infrared data. Finally, a risk assessment model is constructed by incorporating the geometric information from LiDAR point clouds. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves $87 \% \mathrm{mAP}$ in detection accuracy, $88.5 \%$ precision, and $89.2 \%$ risk assessment accuracy, significantly outperforming comparison methods. The study demonstrates that multi-modal data fusion technology can effectively enhance the overall performance of transmission line defect detection and risk assessment, providing a reliable solution for intelligent inspection.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Predicting Oocyte Maturity and Quality in Assisted
authors: Mariyam Khan, Akash More, Namrata Choudhary, Lakhan Padwal, Ganesh Kalaskar
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a rapidly growing tool used for decision-making and predictive analysis in assisted reproductive technology (ART). Accurate assessment of oocyte maturity and quality in IVF/ICSI cycles directly affects fertilization success and embryo development outcomes. Traditional oocyte grading methods rely on the subjective observation of the embryologist, which has the possibility of variability and bias. To address this challenge, AI-based models, specially deep learning and machine vision algorithms, are now analyzing oocyte images and morphology parameters. These models predict oocyte maturity and fertilization potential by identifying micro-level features such as zona pellucida thickness, cytoplasmic granularity, polar body morphology. Recent literature suggests that AI can reduce the workload of embryologists by providing noninvasive and objective evaluation and reducing inter-observer variability. AI-based oocyte assessment has the potential to improve fertilization rates, embryo quality, and live birth outcomes for long-term clinical impact. Future directions will require large annotated datasets and multi-center validation studies to robustly implement AI in clinical practice.

title: Noise and SNR Characteristics Analysis of an Arctic HF Wideband Channel
authors: Yanming Qin, Makun Guo, Kun Xu, Boyu Xu, Ke Du, Changxu Lin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, and Communication (ICAIRC)
abstract: High-frequency (HF) wideband communication channels are subject to significant noise interference, which severely constrains channel quality and link reliability. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) serves as a core metric for evaluating system performance, directly reflecting communication quality. This paper presents a channel sounding campaign conducted on a Qingdao-Arctic HF wideband link. Based on the collected data, the noise and SNR characteristics are analyzed, providing the mean values of noise power and signal power. The analysis demonstrates that the Generalized Extreme Value distribution offers a superior fit to the statistical properties of both parameters. Furthermore, a minimum SNR threshold of 10 dB is established as a prerequisite for achieving reliable transmission. These findings provide valuable insights for HF wideband channel modeling and communication performance evaluation in Arctic environments.

title: Customer Loyalty in the Age of Personalization: A Predictive Analytics Approach for Service-Based Business Models
authors: Parihar Suresh Dahake, Abhijit Gajghate, Pragati Dahake, Rahul Mohare, Pritam Bhadade
publish: 2025 3rd DMIHER International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare, Education and Industry (IDICAIHEI)
abstract: Personalized service delivery has become an important trend that is reshaping consumer engagement and business practices. Research indicates that personalization influences the allocation of resources, aiming to enhance customer satisfaction, trust, and loyalty. Predictive analytics based on individual customer information support the development of customized service systems that can identify patterns and guide targeted marketing efforts. Evaluating the effectiveness of such systems requires tools that can measure future prediction accuracy using real data while considering individual loyalty levels. This study uses Orange software to design a predictive analytics model that estimates customer loyalty based on key personal and behavioral factors. These prediction methods help service-oriented businesses strengthen relationships with existing customers and identify those at risk of leaving. The findings suggest that the influence of loyalty programs that focus on personalization, differentiation, and innovation is more substantial than commonly assumed. They also reinforce the strategic value of retaining current customers, which explains why many companies allocate a growing share of their budgets to retention activities. Four algorithms were tested to ensure both strong performance and ease of interpretation. Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, and Random Forest models were applied and compared. The workflow in Orange included data preparation, model application, performance evaluation, and interpretation. Together, these steps provided a structured approach for understanding customer loyalty and supporting data-driven decision-making.

title: Research on UAV Trajectory Prediction Method Based on Bi-LSTM with Self-Attention Mechanism
authors: Ruojun Shi, Bo Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, and Communication (ICAIRC)
abstract: Under the current conditions of rapid advancements in artificial intelligence and continuous innovation in intelligent manufacturing, drones-as a low-altitude component of integrated air, space, and ground systems-have attracted significant scholarly attention. The three-dimensional nature and high maneuverability of drone trajectories have rendered trajectory prediction a prominent research topic across various related disciplines. To enhance the operational efficiency of drones in tasks relying on trajectory prediction, this paper proposes a Bi-LSTM with Self-Attention model based on the long short-term memory network combined with self-attention mechanism for training unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) trajectory data. Furthermore, physical constraints and trajectory smoothness requirements are incorporated into the model to improve prediction accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves 51.17% and 29.2% higher prediction accuracy compared to GRU and LSTM models, respectively.

title: A Method for Power System Condition Recognition and Fault Diagnosis Based on Warped Clustering Strategy
authors: Yongqi Guo, Zongshang Li, Qingxuan Wei, Yong Chang, Shuainan Guo, Ce Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Smart Grid and Energy Engineering (SGEE)
abstract: With the rapid development of power systems, effective condition recognition and fault diagnosis have become increasingly urgent. To improve the effectiveness of condition recognition and fault diagnosis in power systems, a method for power system condition recognition and fault diagnosis based on warped clustering strategy is proposed in this paper. Firstly, the database covering both different normal and fault conditions is constructed by using simulation data and actual operation data. Secondly, the initial clusters are obtained by using simulation data and condition information. Then the initial clusters are adjusted by using k-nearest neighbor(KNN) in combination with real operation data to construct warped clusters. Finally, condition recognition and fault diagnosis are achieved by KNN based on warped clusters. Case analysis on the IEEE 3-machine 9-node system demonstrates that proposed method markedly enhances the performance of intelligent management and fault diagnosis in power systems.

title: Prediction of Battery Thermal Runaway Gas Products Based on FT-Transformer Neural Network
authors: Haisen Zhang, Hua Xiao, Yonghui Guo, Xiaobin Lin, Xinyue Li, Ximin Huang, Ning Qi, Shufan Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Energy Power and Electrical Technology (CEPET)
abstract: Thermal runaway (TR) remains a critical safety concern for lithium-ion batteries, where the composition of flammable gases produced directly determines combustion and explosion risks. Traditional experimental methods are costly and time-consuming, failing to meet rapid prediction requirements. This paper proposes an FT-Transformer based prediction model for battery TR gas generation, addressing small-sample and multioutput regression challenges. The model achieves high-precision predictions for $\mathbf{1 1}$ gas components including $\mathbf{H}_{\mathbf{2}}$ and $\mathbf{C H}_{4}$. Through feature tokenization and self-attention mechanisms, it effectively captures complex relationships between battery states, charging rates, and gas release. Experimental results demonstrate FTTransformer’s superiority over traditional models such as the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) across multiple evaluation metrics, with an average $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ of 0.9519, verifying its practical utility and advancement in battery safety prediction.
